item.title: Dollar recovers from four-year low as traders await Fed decision
item.description:
The U.S. dollar clawed back some ground on Wednesday after tumbling to a four-year low, as markets turned their attention to the Federal Reserve's first policy decision of 2026.

President Donald Trump's casual dismissal of the currency's recent slide triggered the sharpest single-day drop in the greenback since the tariff upheaval in April. When asked Tuesday whether the dollar had declined too much, Trump told reporters in Iowa, "No, I think it's great," adding that it should "just seek its own level." Traders interpreted the remarks as a green light to sell the U.S. currency aggressively.

item.title: Musk eyes June planetary alignment for record SpaceX IPO
item.description:
Elon Musk has proposed timing SpaceX's potential initial public offering to coincide with a rare planetary alignment in mid-June, according to the Financial Times. The rocket maker is targeting a $1.5 trillion valuation and aims to raise up to $50 billion, which would make it the largest IPO in history.

The company is eyeing mid-June when Jupiter and Venus will appear very close together in the sky for the first time in more than three years, five people familiar with the matter told the Financial Times. On June 8 and 9, the two planets will be positioned within roughly 1.6 degrees of each other, about the width of a thumb held at arm's length, according to the nonprofit Planetary Society. Musk's 55th birthday on June 28 was also a factor in the timing decision, sources said.

item.title: China's solar and wind capacity surpasses coal for first time
item.description:
China installed a record 315 gigawatts of new solar capacity in 2025 alongside 119 gigawatts of wind power, pushing combined wind and solar capacity past coal-based thermal generation for the first time in the nation's history, according to official data released by the National Energy Administration on January 28.

The figures mark a structural shift in the energy mix of the world's largest greenhouse gas emitter. By the end of December, China's cumulative wind and solar capacity reached 1.84 terawatts, exceeding thermal power by 300 million kilowatts and accounting for 47.3 percent of the country's total installed power generation capacity.

item.title: Trump warns Iran 'time is running out' as US naval fleet approaches
item.description:
President Donald Trump issued an urgent ultimatum to Iran on Wednesday, warning that "time is running out" to negotiate a nuclear agreement as a massive US naval fleet approaches the region. The warning escalates tensions weeks after deadly protests rocked Iran and following last year's US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

"Hopefully Iran will quickly 'come to the table' and negotiate a fair and equitable deal — NO NUCLEAR WEAPONS — one that is good for all parties," Trump wrote in a social media post, according to Reuters. "Time is running out, it is truly of the essence!"

Trump explicitly referenced the previous US military strikes on Iran, warning that "the next attack will be far worse" if Tehran does not comply. The president also noted that a "huge armada is making its way to Iran with great speed and power" and would "fulfill its mission with speed and violence if necessary".

item.title: Leaked draft shows Trump's Gaza board would grant him sweeping power
item.description:
A leaked document has revealed that President Donald Trump's newly established Board of Peace would grant him extraordinary authority over Gaza's governance, reconstruction, and legal framework, drawing sharp criticism from humanitarian leaders and sparking divisions among U.S. allies.

The unsigned draft resolution, dated January 22 and obtained by Drop Site News from three independent sources, shows that Trump would serve as chairman with power to sign all resolutions into force, approve military commanders, and appoint key officials throughout the governing apparatus. The document states the Board would hold "all transitional legislative and executive authority, emergency powers, and the administration of justice" over Gaza.

item.title: Bank of Canada holds rates steady, warns Fed independence threats add to global instability
item.description: The Bank of Canada on Wednesday maintained its benchmark interest rate at 2.25 percent, while the U.S. Federal Reserve is widely expected to keep its policy rate unchanged in the 3.5-3.75 percent range when it announces its decision later today. Both central banks are navigating elevated uncertainty, with Governor Tiff Macklem warning that threats to the Fed's independence add to global economic instability.

item.title: Fast-growing trees threaten forest diversity worldwide, study finds
item.description:
The world's forests are undergoing a transformation that may weaken their ecological integrity for decades to come. A comprehensive international study published January 27 in Nature Plants warns that fast-growing tree species are increasingly dominating forest ecosystems worldwide, displacing slower-growing native trees and reducing both biodiversity and long-term carbon storage capacity.

The research team analyzed more than 31,000 tree species globally and found that forests are becoming homogenized as fast-growing varieties such as acacia, eucalyptus, poplar, and pine outcompete specialized native species. Nearly 41 percent of naturalized tree species—those that have established wild populations outside their native ranges—possess traits like rapid growth and small leaves that make them well-suited to disturbed environments but unable to fulfill the ecological roles of the species they replace.

item.title: Federal Reserve holds interest rates steady amid Trump pressure
item.description: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday announced it will leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3.5%-3.75%, marking a pause after three consecutive quarter-point cuts late last year. The widely anticipated decision comes as Chair Jerome Powell navigates unprecedented political pressure from President Donald Trump and a Justice Department investigation that Powell has called a "pretext" for influencing monetary policy.

item.title: East Africa faces drought and faster tectonic rifting as south floods
item.description: East Africa is contending with a dual climate crisis: new scientific research shows that millennia of drying conditions are accelerating the continent's tectonic split, while the region confronts a severe drought in the north and catastrophic flooding in the south.

item.title: Mexico suspends oil shipments to Cuba amid US pressure
item.description:
Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum confirmed Tuesday that her government has at least temporarily suspended oil shipments to Cuba, a move that comes as the Trump administration intensifies efforts to economically isolate the Caribbean island nation. While Sheinbaum insisted the decision was "sovereign" and not made under pressure from the United States, the timing follows weeks of escalating American rhetoric demanding an end to Cuba's energy lifelines.

State oil company Petróleos Mexicanos (Pemex) was scheduled to send a crude shipment aboard the vessel Swift Galaxy in mid-January but removed the cargo from its schedule without explanation, according to documents reviewed by Bloomberg. The cancellation leaves Cuba facing deepening fuel shortages and extended blackouts, with the island already producing only half the electricity it needs.

item.title: German chancellor warns weak dollar burdens exporters
item.description:
German Chancellor Friedrich Merz warned Wednesday that the weakening dollar has become a "considerable additional burden" for Germany's export-oriented economy, while calling on Washington to uphold trade commitments made with the European Union last year.

"We will have to assert ourselves globally against a weak dollar and a strong euro," Merz told reporters in Berlin. "We simply have to become more competitive and stronger, especially given the currency exchange rates."

item.title: Meta to report Q4 earnings amid AI spending surge, layoffs
item.description:
Meta Platforms, Inc. will announce its fourth-quarter 2025 earnings after market close Wednesday as Wall Street scrutinizes the social media giant's aggressive artificial intelligence spending and recent workforce cuts in its virtual reality division.

Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg expect the company to report revenue of approximately $58.4 billion, a 21% year-over-year increase, with earnings per share of around $8.16 to $8.21. Bank of America analysts project the company could beat consensus estimates, forecasting revenue of $59.2 billion and EPS of $8.27.

item.title: Microsoft shares fall despite beating cloud revenue expectations
item.description:
Microsoft reported stronger-than-expected quarterly results on Wednesday, but its shares fell more than 7% in extended trading as investors questioned whether the tech giant's cloud growth justifies the scale of its artificial intelligence investments.

The company posted fiscal second-quarter revenue of $81.3 billion, up 17% year-over-year and slightly above the $80.3 billion analysts had expected. Earnings per share of $5.16 also beat Wall Street estimates of $3.92. Azure, the cloud computing division closely watched by investors, grew 39%—narrowly edging past the 38.8% consensus estimate.

item.title: Dutch court orders Netherlands to protect Bonaire from climate change
item.description:
A Dutch court on Wednesday ruled that the Netherlands violated the human rights of residents on the Caribbean island of Bonaire by failing to protect them from climate change, ordering the government to set binding emission reduction targets within 18 months and implement a comprehensive adaptation plan by 2030.

The Hague District Court found that the Dutch state discriminated against Bonaire's approximately 20,000 residents by not devising timely climate protections for the low-lying island, which faces rising sea levels, extreme weather, and coral reef degradation.

item.title: Trump threatens to cut Iraq support over al-Maliki nomination
item.description:
President Donald Trump warned Iraq on Tuesday that the United States will end support for the country if former Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki returns to power, threatening to restrict Iraq's access to its oil revenues held at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

"Last time Maliki was in power, the Country descended into poverty and total chaos. That should not be allowed to happen again," Trump wrote on Truth Social. "Because of his insane policies and ideologies, if elected, the United States of America will no longer help Iraq and, if we are not there to help, Iraq has ZERO chance of Success, Prosperity, or Freedom. MAKE IRAQ GREAT AGAIN!".

Al-Maliki, 75, rejected the warning on Wednesday, vowing to continue his bid for the premiership. "We categorically reject the blatant American interference in Iraq's internal affairs," he wrote on X, calling Trump's remarks "a violation of sovereignty and a contravention of the democratic order in Iraq since 2003".

item.title: US intelligence doubts Venezuela's Rodríguez will cut ties with adversaries
item.description:
Recent U.S. intelligence assessments have cast doubt on whether Venezuela's interim President Delcy Rodríguez will comply with the Trump administration's demands to formally cut diplomatic and economic ties with Iran, China, and Russia, according to four people familiar with the reports.

The intelligence findings, disclosed as Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday, underscore Washington's uncertain position in Venezuela nearly a month after U.S. special forces captured former President Nicolás Maduro on January 3.

item.title: Tesla to discontinue Model S and Model X to make Optimus robots
item.description:
Tesla will discontinue production of its Model S sedan and Model X SUV by the end of the second quarter of 2026, CEO Elon Musk announced Wednesday during the company's fourth-quarter earnings call. The Fremont, California factory lines that currently build those vehicles will be converted to manufacture Optimus humanoid robots, with a target capacity of one million units annually.

"It's time to basically bring the Model S and X programs to an end with an honorable discharge, because we're really moving into a future that is based on autonomy," Musk said during the call, according to TechCrunch. "If you're interested in buying a Model S and X, now would be the time to order it."

item.title: Scientists detail plans to study asteroid's potential moon strike
item.description:
A 60-meter-wide asteroid discovered just over a year ago carries a small but notable chance of striking the moon in late 2032, and researchers worldwide are preparing for what could be the most energetic lunar impact ever recorded in human history.

Asteroid 2024 YR4, which was first detected on December 27, 2024, at the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System telescope in Chile, has approximately a 4% probability of colliding with the moon on December 22, 2032. While that means there is a 96% chance the asteroid will miss, scientists are treating the possibility as both a potential hazard and a rare scientific opportunity.

item.title: Gold surges past $5,500 to record high on safe-haven demand
item.description:
Gold prices vaulted past $5,400 per ounce on Wednesday, extending an explosive rally that has seen the precious metal gain more than 25% since the start of the year, as investors sought refuge from mounting geopolitical risks and a weakening dollar ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates steady.

The yellow metal climbed as much as 4% during the session, with spot gold reaching $5,393.19 an ounce and U.S. gold futures for February settling 4.3% higher at $5,303.60, according to Reuters. By early Thursday trading in Asia, gold had pushed above $5,500 per ounce, marking gains of more than $500 over four sessions since first breaking the $5,000 barrier on Monday.

item.title: Rubio says Donetsk territory is last major hurdle in Ukraine talks
item.description:
Negotiations to end the nearly four-year war between Russia and Ukraine have narrowed to a single, pivotal issue: control over Ukraine's eastern Donetsk region. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday that resolving the territorial dispute remains "very difficult," even as both sides prepare for another round of talks in Abu Dhabi scheduled for February 1.

"It's still a gap, but at least we've been able to narrow down the issue set to one central one," Rubio said during testimony. He indicated there may be American participation in the upcoming discussions, though President Donald Trump's key envoys—Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner—will not attend.
